column2: pronounced [sǐː.kʰíw]) is a district (amphoe) in the western part of Nakhon Ratchasima Province

column1: Originally known as Mueang Nakhon Chantuek
column2: Sikhio is an ancient frontier city between the Thai-dominated Chao Phraya valley and the Lao-dominated Khorat Plateau. Nakhon Chantuek was controlled directly by the central government of Siam.

column1: On 1 April 1898 it became a subordinate mueang of Nakhon Ratchasima. The district office was moved to Ban Nong Bua in 1901
column2: and moved again to Ban Sikhio in 1906
column3: both times because the original location was malaria infected.

column1: In 1939 the district was renamed from Chanthuek to Sikhio.
The district is in the Dong Phaya Yen mountain range.
Neighbouring districts are (from the north clockwise): Dan Khun Thot
column3: and Pak Chong of Nakhon Ratchasima; Muak Lek of Saraburi Province; and Lam Sonthi of Lopburi Province.

column1: The district is divided into 12 sub-districts (tambons)
column2: which are further subdivided into 170 villages (mubans). The town (thesaban mueang) Sikhio covers parts of tambons Sikhio and Mittraphap. There are another four sub-district municipalities (thesaban tambons)
column3: Lad Bua Khao covering parts of tambon Lad Bua Khao
column4: and Khlong Phai covering parts of tambon Khlong Phai
column5: Mueang Sikhio. Those parts of tambon Sikhio not covered by the town Sikhio
column6: and Nong Nam Sai the full same-named sub-district. There are another 10 tambon administrative organizations (TAO).
